questions.text: Glanzmann thrombasthenia is due to defect in:
questions.solution:
• GpIIb/IIIa (Correct Answer : Choice A): This glycoprotein complex is essential for platelet aggregation. It acts as a receptor for fibrinogen and von Willebrand factor (vWF), enabling platelet-platelet adhesion. A deficiency or dysfunction leads to impaired clot formation.

Incorrect choices explanation:

  • GpIb-IX (Choice B): This is the vWF receptor on platelets, defective in Bernard-Soulier syndrome, not Glanzmann thrombasthenia.
  • CD68 (Choice C): A marker for macrophages and monocytes, unrelated to platelet function.
  • Von Willebrand Factor (Choice D): A large glycoprotein involved in platelet adhesion but not aggregation. Deficiency results in von Willebrand disease, not Glanzmann thrombasthenia.

Key takeaway: Glanzmann Thrombasthenia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa (GpIIb/IIIa) complex on platelet membranes. This results in defective platelet aggregation and an increased risk of bleeding.

questions.text: Chromosome number of partial hydatidiform mole is:
questions.solution:
A partial hydatidiform mole (PHM) arises due to the fertilization of an ovum by two sperm (dispermy), leading to a triploid karyotype (69 chromosomes). The common chromosomal compositions observed in PHM are:

  • 69,XXX(most common)
  • 69,XXY
  • 69,XYY(rare)

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: 46 XX

  • A 46,XX karyotype is seen in complete hydatidiform moles, which occur due to fertilization of an empty ovumby a single sperm that duplicates its DNA.

Choice B: 46 XY

  • Similar to 46,XX, a 46,XY karyotype is also found in complete moles, not partial moles.

Choice D: Any of the Above

  • Only triploid (69) karyotypes are found in PHM, making this choice incorrect.

Key takeaway:

Partial Hydatidiform Mole:

  • Triploidy (69 chromosomes)
  • Fetal parts may be present
  • Less trophoblastic proliferation than complete mole

choices.text: Only C and D are true
Only A and B are true

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about alpha 1 Antitrypsin?
(A): Inhibits elastase
(B): Deficiency is associated with pan acinar emphysema
(C): Inhibits trypsin activating protease
(D): Coded by PiMM gene
questions.solution:
Choice A: Inhibit neutrophil elastase, protecting lung tissues from proteolytic damage (Correct)

This is the primary function of AAT. Neutrophil elastase is released by neutrophils to fight infection, but if left unchecked, it can damage healthy lung tissue. AAT acts as a protective shield.

Incorrect choices explanation:

Choice B: Deficiency of AAT leads to unregulated elastase activity, which destroys alveolar walls, causing panacinar emphysema (Correct)

This is the key clinical consequence of AAT deficiency. Without enough AAT, elastase destroys the alveoli (air sacs) in the lungs, leading to emphysema. The "panacinar" type means the damage is evenly distributed throughout the acinus (the functional respiratory unit).

Choice C: Primarily inhibit trypsin activating protease ( Incorrect)

While AAT is a serine protease inhibitor (serpin), its main target is neutrophil elastase, not trypsin activating protease. Trypsin is more related to digestive processes.

Choice D: The AAT gene is SERPINA1, with PiMM being the normal genotype (Correct)

SERPINA1 is indeed the gene that encodes AAT. The PiMM genotype is the most common and is associated with normal AAT levels. Other genotypes, like PiZZ, are associated with severe deficiency.

Key takeaway: Deficiency of AAT leads to unregulated elastase activity, which destroys alveolar walls, causing panacinar emphysema

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
1) IL-6 (Interleukin-6):

IL-6 is a cytokine that plays a crucial role in inflammation and the acute phase response.

It's produced by various cells, including macrophages, and acts as an endogenous pyrogen, meaning it causes fever from within the body.

Therefore, 1 matches with B.

2) IL-8 (Interleukin-8):

IL-8 is a chemokine that attracts neutrophils to sites of inflammation.

It is also an endogenous pyrogen.

Therefore 2 matches with B.

3) IFN-gamma (Interferon-gamma):

IFN-gamma is a cytokine primarily produced by T cells and natural killer cells.

It also acts as an endogenous pyrogen.

Therefore 3 matches with B.

4) Lipopolysaccharide (LPS):

LPS is a component of the cell wall of gram-negative bacteria.

It's a potent exogenous pyrogen, meaning it causes fever from outside the body. It triggers the release of endogenous pyrogens like IL-6.

Therefore, 4 matches with A.

Therefore the correct answer is (D): 1-B 2-B 3-B 4-A

questions.text: Bellini duct cancer is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
You're right, Bellini duct carcinoma is a rare type of renal cell carcinoma, which means it originates in the kidney. Here's a breakdown:

Bellini Ducts (Ducts of Bellini):

These are the largest collecting ducts within the kidneys.

They are located in the renal medulla, which is the inner part of the kidney.

Their primary function is to transport urine from the nephrons (the functional units of the kidney) to the renal pelvis.

Bellini Duct Carcinoma:

Incorrect choices explanation:

(Choice A) Liver: Liver cancers originate in the liver tissue, not the Bellini ducts.

(Choice C) Heart: Heart cancers are rare and originate in the heart tissue, not the Bellini ducts.

(Choice D) Spleen: Spleen cancers are also rare and originate in the spleen tissue, not the Bellini ducts

Key takeaway: This is a rare and aggressive form of renal cell carcinoma that arises from the epithelial cells lining the Bellini ducts.

It is often associated with poor prognosis due to its aggressive nature and tendency to metastasize (spread to other parts of the body).

questions.text: Which one of the following is a function of PGI2?
questions.solution:
As we discussed, PGI2 (prostacyclin) is primarily produced by endothelial cells.

Its key functions are to relax vascular smooth muscle, causing vasodilation (widening of blood vessels), and to increase cAMP levels in platelets, inhibiting their aggregation (clumping).

Incorrect choices explanation :

(Choice A) Vasoconstriction and inhibits platelet aggregation:

PGI2 does inhibit platelet aggregation, but it causes vasodilation, not vasoconstriction.

(Choice C) Vasoconstriction and increases platelet aggregation:

This describes the function of thromboxane A2 (TXA2), not PGI2.

(Choice D) Vasodilator and increases platelet aggregation:

PGI2 causes vasodilation, but it inhibits, not increases, platelet aggregation


Key takeaway:

Vasodilation: PGD2, PGE1, PGE2, PGI

choices.text: Calcification and fibrosis bridging across valvular commissures
Acute inflammation leading to valvular damage

questions.text: Fish mouth stenosis in rheumatic heart disease is due to which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Rheumatic Heart Disease (RHD) and Mitral Stenosis:

RHD is a complication of untreated streptococcal pharyngitis (strep throat).

It involves an autoimmune reaction that damages heart valves, particularly the mitral valve.

Mitral stenosis, a narrowing of the mitral valve, is a common consequence of RHD.

"Fish mouth stenosis" is a descriptive term of the appearance of the stenotic mitral valve.

Incorrect choices explanation:

(Choice B) Fibrinoid necrosis:

Fibrinoid necrosis is seen in conditions like vasculitis, not primarily in the chronic valvular changes of RHD.

(Choice C) Acute inflammation leading to valvular damage:

While acute inflammation initiates the process in RHD, "fish mouth stenosis" is a result of the chronic, long-term effects of that inflammation, not the acute phase itself.

(Choice D) Myxomatous degeneration of the valve:

Myxomatous degeneration is associated with mitral valve prolapse, not mitral stenosis in RHD. This involves weakening and stretching of the valve leaflets, not fusion and calcification.

Key takeaway:

Mechanism of Fish Mouth Stenosis:

The primary mechanism is calcification and fibrosis bridging across valvular commissures.

The inflammatory process in RHD leads to thickening and scarring of the valve leaflets.

The commissures (the points where the leaflets meet) fuse together, resulting in a narrowed, rigid orifice that resembles a fish mouth.

Calcium deposits further stiffen the valve.

questions.text: Which of the following is positive in Follicular lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Here the question is based on immunophenotypic markers that are seen in the image below.


Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice B: Bcl-6

  • Bcl-6 is also positive in follicular lymphoma, but it is not specific.
  • It is found in other B-cell lymphomas, including diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL).

Choice C: Bcl-1

  • Bcl-1 is associated with mantle cell lymphoma, not follicular lymphoma.
  • It is overexpressed due to the t(11;14) translocation, leading to cyclin D1 overexpression.

Choice D: Bcl-10

  • Bcl-10 is associated with MALT lymphoma (marginal zone lymphoma), not follicular lymphoma.

Key takeaway: Follicular cell lymphoma is the only lymphoma that is BCL2 positive.

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are autosomal recessive disorder/disorders?
(A): Sickle cell anemia
(B): Friedreich Ataxia
(C): Hemochromatosis
(D): Huntington's chorea
questions.solution:
Key Takeaway: AUTOSOMAL RECESSIVE DISORDERS

Mnemonic: ABCDEFGHI

A- Albinism, Alkaptonuria, Ataxia-telangiectasia

B-Beta-thalassemia, Sickle cell anemia

C-Cystic fibrosis, Congenital adrenal hyperplasia

D-Deafness

E-Emphysema (alpha1-antitrypsin deficiency)

F-Friedrich's ataxia

G-Gaucher's disease, Galactosemia

H-Homocystinuria, Hemochromatosis

I-Inborn errors of metabolism

choices.text: Only C and D are true

questions.text:
True regarding mitochondrial DNA:
A. 1% of cellular DNA, 13 Proteins of respiratory chain
B. Don't show heteroplasmy
C. AGA and AGG are stop codon in mitochondrial DNA
D. Kearns Sayre Syndrome is a large deletion in mitochondrial DNA
questions.solution:
Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is distinct from nuclear DNA and has unique characteristics, including its maternal inheritance, circular structure, and high mutation rate.

Why is Choice B (A, C, D) Correct?

  1. Statement A (1% of cellular DNA, 13 proteins of the respiratory chain) → TRUE
    • Mitochondrial DNA constitutes about 1% of total cellular DNA.
    • mtDNA encodes 13 essential proteins involved in oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS), which is part of the electron transport chain (ETC).
    • It also encodes 22 tRNAs and 2 rRNAs for mitochondrial protein synthesis.
  2. Statement C (AGA and AGG are stop codons in mitochondrial DNA) → TRUE
    • Unlike nuclear DNA, where AGA and AGG code for arginine, in mitochondrial DNA, they function as stop codons.
    • The mitochondria have a different genetic code than nuclear DNA.
  3. Statement D (Kearns-Sayre Syndrome is due to large deletions in mitochondrial DNA) → TRUE
    • Kearns-Sayre Syndrome (KSS) is a mitochondrial disorder caused by large deletions (1-10 kb) in mtDNA.
    • It leads to progressive external ophthalmoplegia, cardiac conduction defects, and myopathy.

Why is Choice B (Don't show heteroplasmy) Incorrect?

  • Statement B (Mitochondrial DNA does not show heteroplasmy) → FALSE
    • Heteroplasmy refers to the presence of both normal and mutated mtDNA within the same cell.
    • Mitochondrial diseases often show variable expression due to differences in heteroplasmy levels in different tissues.
  • Statements A, C, and D are correct, making choice (B) the right choice.
  • Statement B is incorrect because mitochondrial DNA does exhibit heteroplasmy, which influences the severity of mitochondrial disorders.

Major Histocompatibility Complex Class II (MHC-II)

Correct Answer: (A) Antigen Presenting Cells (APCs)

Explanation:

MHC Class II (MHC-II) molecules are specifically expressed on antigen-presenting cells (APCs), which include:

  • Dendritic cells
  • Macrophages
  • B lymphocytes (B cells)

Incorrect choices explanation:

  • (Choice B) Red Blood Cells:
    • RBCs lack a nucleus and MHC molecules(they do not present antigens).
  • (Choice C) Platelets:
    • Platelets are primarily involved in clottingand do not express MHC-II.
  • (Choice D) Epithelial Cells:
    • Epithelial cells express MHC-I (not MHC-II), as MHC-I is present on all nucleated cells.

Key takeaway: These APCs play a crucial role in the adaptive immune response by presenting processed antigens to CD4+ T helper cells (Th cells), which then coordinate immune activation.

MHC-II Pathway Mechanism:

  1. Antigen Uptake: APCs engulf pathogens via phagocytosis or endocytosis.
  2. Antigen Processing: The engulfed pathogen is broken down into smaller peptide fragments.
  3. MHC-II Loading: These peptides are loaded onto MHC-II molecules inside the endosomal compartment.
  4. Presentation to CD4+ T Cells: The MHC-II-peptide complex is transported to the APC surface, where it interacts with CD4+ T helper cells.
  5. Immune Activation: This interaction stimulates cytokine release, activating other immune cells like B cells (for antibody production) and macrophages (for phagocytosis).

questions.text: A 35-year-old female on OCPs presented with intermittent abdominal pain and intermittent diarrhea. Appearance of intestine is an image given below. Endoscopy showed ileum involvement with rectal sparing. Which of the following feature is specific to given disease?
questions.solution:
Why (Choice A) Transmural Involvement is the Best Answer:

  • It is the defining histological feature of Crohn's disease.
  • It explains key complications of Crohn's, such as fistulas, strictures, and abscess formation, which occur due to full-thickness inflammation.
  • Involvement of the ileum with rectal sparing is another classical feature of Crohn's, making transmural involvement the best choice.

Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:

  • (Choice B) Presence of Polyps
    • While inflammatory polyps (pseudopolyps) can be seen in both Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, they are not a distinguishing feature.
    • Pseudopolyps result from regenerating mucosa in areas of chronic inflammation but are more commonly associated with ulcerative colitis.
  • (Choice C) Mucosal Edema
    • Mucosal edema occurs in many inflammatory conditions of the gut, including both Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.
    • Since it is not exclusive to Crohn's, it cannot be used as a diagnostic hallmark.
  • (Choice D) Lymphocyte Infiltrate
    • Lymphocytic infiltration is a general histopathological feature of inflammation, seen in both Crohn's and ulcerative colitis.
    • Crohn's disease typically shows granulomatous inflammation, which is more specific, while ulcerative colitis shows crypt abscesses.

Key takeaway:

Transmural inflammation is the defining characteristic of Crohn's disease.

The ileum involvement with rectal sparing also points strongly towards Crohn's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following type of necrosis is seen in blood vessel due to immune complex mediated damage?
questions.solution:
Choice C: Fibrinoid Necrosis

  • Fibrinoid necrosis occurs in blood vessels due to immune complex-mediated damage, often seen in vasculitis and malignant hypertension.
  • It is characterized by fibrin deposition in vessel walls, leading to a pink, eosinophilic appearance under a microscope.
  • Causes include:
    • Immune complex vasculitis(e.g., Polyarteritis Nodosa)
    • Severe hypertension
    • Preeclampsia

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Coagulative Necrosis

  • Seen in ischemic infarcts(except in the brain).
  • Preserved tissue architecture with loss of nuclei and cytoplasmic eosinophilia.
  • Common in heart, kidney, spleen but not blood vessels.

Choice B: Liquefactive Necrosis

  • Seen in brain infarcts and abscesses.
  • Caused by enzymatic digestion of dead tissue into a liquid mass.
  • Common in bacterial infections (pus formation) and ischemic strokes of the brain.

Choice D: Caseous Necrosis

  • Cheese-like necrosis, seen in tuberculosis and some fungal infections.
  • Granulomatous inflammation with a mix of macrophages, lymphocytes, and necrotic debris.

Key Takeaway:

Coagulative necrosis - Architecture dead tissue (Infract)

Liquefactive necrosis - Digestion of dead tissue into viscous liquid (Brain)

Caseous necrosis - Cheese like(TB)

Fibrinoid necrosis - is seen in immune complex-mediated vascular damage, commonly in vasculitis and malignant hypertension.

Fibrinoid necrosis is a special form of vascular damage usually seen in immune reactions involving blood vessels. It typically occurs when complexes of antigens and antibodies are deposited in the walls of arteries. Deposits of these immune complexes, together with plasma proteins that has leaked out of vessels, result in a bright pink and amorphous appearance in H&E stains called "fibrinoid" (fibrin-like) by pathologists (Fig. 2.11). The immunologically mediated vasculitis syndromes in which this type of vascular injury is seen are described in Chapter 11.

questions.text: Caspase involved in activation of IL-1 is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Caspase Involved in Activation of IL-1

Caspase-1 is a key enzyme involved in the activation of interleukin-1 beta (IL-1β) and interleukin-18 (IL-18), both of which play essential roles in the inflammatory response. It is a part of the inflammasome complex, which is activated in response to pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) and danger-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs).

Mechanism of Caspase-1 Activation:

  1. Recognition of Danger Signals: Pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) such as NOD-like receptors (NLRs)detect infections or cellular damage.
  2. Inflammasome Formation: Activation of NLRP3, AIM2, or other inflammasomesleads to the recruitment of pro-caspase-1.
  3. Caspase-1 Activation: Once activated, caspase-1 cleaves pro-IL-1β into its active form (IL-1β), which is then secreted to mediate inflammation and immune response.

Incorrect choices explanation:

  • Caspase-3(Choice B) is involved in apoptosis (cell death), not inflammation.
  • Caspase-5(Choice C) is sometimes associated with inflammasome activation but is not the primary enzyme responsible for IL-1β activation.
  • Caspase-8(Choice D) is a key regulator of extrinsic apoptosis, primarily activated by death receptor signaling (e.g., Fas-FasL pathway).

Key takeaway:

  • Excess IL-1β production is linked to autoinflammatory diseases, such as Cryopyrin-Associated Periodic Syndromes (CAPS), gout, and rheumatoid arthritis.
  • IL-1 inhibitors (e.g., Anakinra, Canakinumab) are used in treating autoinflammatory and autoimmune disorders.

choices.text: 10% female carriers have mental disability

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Fragile X syndrome?
questions.solution:
Fragile X syndrome (FXS) is the most common inherited cause of intellectual disability and autism spectrum disorder (ASD). It results from a CGG triplet repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene located on the X chromosome.

Males with full mutations (>200 CGG repeats) exhibit moderate to severe intellectual disability, with an average IQ ranging between 20-40. This leads to significant developmental delays, learning disabilities, and behavioral challenges such as speech delay, hyperactivity, and autistic-like behaviors.

Incorrect choices explanation:

Choice A (CAG repeat mutation) is incorrect because Fragile X syndrome is caused by CGG repeats, whereas CAG repeats are associated with Huntington's disease.

Choice B (10% of female carriers have mental disability) underestimates the true percentage, as around 50% of female carriers show some degree of cognitive impairment, though usually milder than in males.

Choice D (Micro-orchidism in affected males) is incorrect because affected males typically develop macroorchidism (enlarged testes) post-puberty, not small testes.

Key takeaway:

Fragile x syndrome : Intellectual Disability: IQ typically ranges from 20-40 in affected males.

Physical Features: Long face, prominent jaw, large ears, and high-arched palate.

Macroorchidism: Testicular enlargement is a common post-pubertal feature.

questions.text: Which of the following is autosomal dominant in inheritance?
questions.solution:
Achondroplasia:

Achondroplasia is the most common cause of dwarfism and follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern. It results from a gain-of-function mutation in the FGFR3 gene (Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor 3), located on chromosome 4p16.3. This mutation inhibits chondrocyte proliferation, leading to defective endochondral ossification, primarily affecting long bones

Incorrect choices explanation:

(Choice A) Sickle cell disease:

This is an autosomal recessive disorder. Two copies of the mutated gene are required for the disease to develop.

(Choice C) Hemochromatosis:

While some forms can be autosomal recessive, some can also be autosomal dominant, but most commonly it is autosomal recessive.

(Choice D) Wiscott Aldrich syndrome:

This is an X-linked recessive disorder. The mutated gene is located on the X chromosome, and males are primarily affected.


KEY TAKEAWAY:

Achondroplasia:

  • This is the most common form of dwarfism.
  • It's caused by a mutation in the FGFR3 gene.
  • Only one copy of the mutated gene is needed for the condition to manifest, hence it's autosomal dominant.

questions.text: Which of the following is an anti-apoptotic gene?
questions.solution:
Regulation is primarily by the Bcl-2 family of genes located on chromosome 18.

Choice A: BCL-2

  • BCL-2 is an anti-apoptotic gene located on chromosome 18.
  • It prevents apoptosis by inhibiting the release of cytochrome c from mitochondria, thereby blocking caspase activation.
  • Overexpression of BCL-2 is seen in Follicular Lymphoma (t(14;18) translocation), leading to cancer cell survival.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice B: BCL-XS

  • BCL-XS is a pro-apoptotic gene.
  • It acts as a dominant-negative inhibitor of BCL-2, promoting apoptosis.

Choice C: BAX

  • BAX is a pro-apoptotic gene that promotes mitochondrial membrane permeabilization, leading to cytochrome c release and apoptosis.

Choice D: BAK

  • BAK is also a pro-apoptotic gene that functions similarly to BAX by forming pores in the mitochondrial membrane.

Key Takeaway: Some members of this family like BAK,BAX, Bcl-xs (to remember, S for stimulating apoptosis) stimulate apoptosis whereas others like Bcl-2, Bcl-xl,MCL (to remember, L for lower apoptosis),etc inhibit apoptosis.
